ratings.question_text: The readings/cases/textbooks used in this course were __________ .
Out-of-class assignments for this course were ___________ to my learning.
The workload for this course in comparison to other courses was ___________.
The pace of this class was ____________ for optimal learning.
Overall, the teaching assistant for this course was accessible, organized, and able to explain concepts clearly and thoroughly.
Field trips were well designed and ran smoothly.
I learned a lot from field trips.
How clearly does the instructor provide explanations of conceptual material?
How responsive to student comments was the instructor?
I would give the instructor of this class an overall rating of:
I would give this course an overall rating of:
Apart from how well the course was taught, how valuable is the course to students with interests similar to yours?
Did you participate in a work group as part of this course?

narratives.question_text: Please identify the teaching assistant with whom you interacted most closely _____________________ .
comments: Instructor: Christopher Hebdon  Chris
Instructor: Christopher Hebdon  Chris
Instructor: Christopher Hebdon  Chris Hebdon
Instructor: Christopher Hebdon  Chris Hebdon
Instructor: Christopher Hebdon  Chris Hebdon
Instructor: Christopher Hebdon  Chris
Instructor: Christopher Hebdon  Chris Hebdon
Instructor: Christopher Hebdon  Chris Hebdon
Instructor: Christopher Hebdon  Chris Hebdon
Instructor: Christopher Hebdon  Chris
Instructor: Christopher Hebdon  Christopher Hebdon
Instructor: Christopher Hebdon  Chris
Instructor: Christopher Hebdon  Christopher Hebdon was the only teaching fellow for the course.

narratives.question_text: What were the strengths and weaknesses of your teaching assistant
comments: Instructor: Christopher Hebdon  Weakness: We did not get grades back for our critiques in a timely manner so we were unable to incorporate them into our next critique. Strengths: Everything else. He is very thoughtful and encourages you to question what you read. He helps you think through your own ideas and research, and is always available to talk.
Instructor: Christopher Hebdon  I did not interact much one on one with Chris, but he seemed very approachable and willing to help.
Instructor: Christopher Hebdon  Chris was a wonderful Teaching Fellow. He made himself available to the class, was thoughtful in his feedback, and has interesting ideas about the course material.
Instructor: Christopher Hebdon  Chris was a great TA. His input during class were insightful.

Instructor: Christopher Hebdon  Chris is very knowledgable, and a great help to students with questions and concerns. His lecture style is a bit dense and at times difficult to follow, but other than that he was an effective teaching assistant.
Instructor: Christopher Hebdon  He was great at responding to emails, his explanations of concepts was easy to understand and his feedback on papers was very helpful.

Instructor: Christopher Hebdon  Overall Chris was very helpful and contributed significantly to the content of the course. Grading of the reading responses was slightly delayed, which would have been helpful to have earlier, but other than that he was fantastic.
Instructor: Christopher Hebdon  Chris was very helpful in discussion sections, steering the discussion and making insightful comments, which encouraged us to take our analysis further.
Instructor: Christopher Hebdon  He knew a lot of t5he literature we read as well as some other works that were useful to the subject matter.

Instructor: Christopher Hebdon  Chris is well versed in the related literature. While it was nice to get his comments on my three commentaries, they came after I had already handed in all three, so I could not apply any of his advice to future work.

narratives.question_text: Use the space below to comment on questions 1-14, if you wish
comments: Best course, best professor, best TA, best experience.
Lots of reading for the class! Also, lectures are really long!
I thoroughly enjoyed this class.

I had not studied anthropology before this course, so that aspect was very useful. Overall, I learned more about anthropology itself than how to apply it to the environmental issues I am interested in.

narratives.question_text: What were the best aspects of this course?
comments: Thinking different.
The readings and the class discussions
Well selected syllabus, opportunity to interact with guest lecturers presenting manuscripts in progress was unique and enlightening

The best aspects of the course were the readings and the instructors review of the material. He shed light on the readings, and made you question the status quo of conservation and development. It changed the way I view the aid and development field, and hopefully with my now critical eye, I can improve the way it works.
I really enjoyed the readings. I only wished that there were a few more contemporary (post 2000) readings mixed in with the classics.

The lectures by Professor Dove were amazing. You can tell that a significant amount of time and thought went into preparing the lecture and it shows. It helped give the readings a strong context, asked provocative questions, and stimulated interest in the material. The guest lectures were very interesting--particularly Michael Hathaway. Keep that part of the course for sure!
I enjoyed all of the topics covered.
The readings and discussions were great and helped a lot in expanding critical thinking.
The pacing and design of the course, the way concepts were grouped, and the supporting readings and discussions were exceptional.

Professor Dove's lectures were high points of the course. He was always well-organized, and his comments were insightful and thought-provoking. The information presented enabled me to examine new angles of the work I am engaged in and of environmental and development programs in general. Particularly useful and practical were the lectures focused on how to appropriately engage with communities and informants.
Classroom discussions.

narratives.question_text: What aspects of this course need the most improvement?
comments: Instead of a 1 paragraph summary about the intended topic of the final paper, a 3-5 page outline or some other more lengthy requirement would be helpful to encourage students to organize their thinking and think deeply about their topic in advance of writing the final paper
If the students can get a transcript of the instructors speeches, that would be most helpful.

I think the lectures and discussions could have been more dynamic. They were interesting, but dragged on a bit. I thought the way they were structured last semester, the same amount of material could have been covered in 2 hours instead of 3.
I would pick one book between "Political Economy of Soil Erosion" and "Uncertainty on a Himalayan Scale"--they are similar and it would create space to add a different book.
More case studies on successful case studies where an anthropological angle bought a positive change.
In some of my classes the teaching assistant took part in discussion group meetings before the class, this could be helpful in this class as well.
The 3 hour block of class was a bit long, and the way reading week sign-ups were done was a bit confusing, but both those are minor.

It would be extremely helpful to have the mandatory opportunity to meet with the professor before presenting in class as a discussion leader. This would have helped to ensure that the discussion section brought out main important points that the professor hoped we would discuss. A pre-class meeting with Prof. Dove would be beneficial to the presenters and the class alike. This is particularly critical for topics/readings that did not have a clear link to the previous topics, such as We Shall Now Praise Famous Men. Otherwise the topics presented and discussed a times seemed disjointed.
On multiple weeks, there was too much reading for me to get to it all, so I had to prioritize.

narratives.question_text: Was the relationship between the course lectures and discussion/lab section
comments: I found the changing formats of the class-led discussions distracting, simple roundtable discussion of the readings seemed to work better than any of the "creative" alternatives
the course lectures and discussions went well together. The readings were very interesting as well.

Very effective. Student led discussions helped tease out different aspects of the topic, though at times they could have been a bit more structured. It was great how strongly linked the larger class concepts, readings, lecture, and discussion were all linked.
This varied as different groups of students were in charge of running the discussion each week.

narratives.question_text: Discuss, if you wish, how this course fits into your overall program.  (Please feel free to describe how the course relates to your academic background.)
comments: Should be mandatory.
The program was an eye opener and a confirmation of many observations i have seen in the field. I also learnt to view things with objectivity.

This course fit into my overall program by giving me a theoretical overview of the aid and development field. It made me question the current operations and assumptions of the field, and will help me to be critical when designing my research.
Though I am not focusing particularly in anthropology, from an intellectual perspective, this was a great class. I learnt a lot.
It is a requirement for my specialization but I also found it helpful for my career goals. It changes my perspective on environmental work and research.
This is the only social science course that I plan to take at FES. It was useful complement to more technical and leadership-focused coursework.

narratives.question_text: Why did you take this course?
comments: I heard great reviews about the instructor and I wanted to confirm the same. His perspectives and experience are worth the 3 hours every week
Foundations course relevant to my interests
I am potentially interested in the aid and development field. I am interested in social science research.
To understand how anthropology looks at environmental problems.

With a fairly extensive background in the quantitative/technical aspects of environmental science, I was looking to develop a base in the environmental humanities/social sciences. This course was exactly that.
It was a requirement for my specialization and I had an interest for the topic of the course.
Learn more about issues that come with development in urban areas.

Although as an MESc student I am not required to take any foundation courses, I want to take one because I don't have an academic background in environmental studies nor science. As I am particularly interested in climate change communication, the description of this course made it sound appropriate.

narratives.question_text: Did the knowledge/skills that you gained from the course meet your expectations ?
comments: Seeing things from a different perspective.
It sure did, and exceeded
Yes, mostly. Perhaps more explicit introduction to some theory.
It did but at the same time it left me a bit depressed
Definitely, it improved my critical thinking.
Absolutely. This course exceeded my expectations.
Yes.
Yes
Yes

narratives.question_text: If yes, what were the advantages and disadvantages of the group work?
comments: I enjoyed working as a group to lead in-class discussions!
I got to learn how to look at issues and topics with different lenses
Biggest advantage of the group work was meeting with a few classmates in an out-of-class session to more deeply discuss the readings
It was really great to work in groups for the commentaries - I made friends and I learnt better.
It was helpful to discuss the readings with the discussion group prior to class.

It was good to listen to others' thoughts and reactions to the readings. Everyone had a different take on the literature based on their own experiences and background. I found it a very enriching experience to work with other members of the class to put together the discussion sections.
People looked at the materials from different backgrounds this made for interesting discussions. Logistics for meeting would be a challenge.

The diversity of backgrounds (both academic and international) of the people in my groups made for enlightening conversations. Some of the groups were too big for everyone to really have a role in facilitating the group discussion in class.

narratives.question_text: For students who might consider taking this course, what advice would you give them?
comments: If you ever want to work in developing countries, with or without international/local agencies, this course is for you
Start the paper early

This is a great course and really makes you question the existing power structures. Sometimes it may be frustrating because it critiques but often times does not provide a way forward. It helps you really understand organizations and assumptions in the aid and development field.

The course is primarily geared towards international environmental development. However, even if this is not a direct interest, the course is excellent in providing a new way to critically examine and dissect complex environmental and political issues.
I would definitely recommend the course; however, I would recommend to balance the semester's work load by taking other courses that less reading.

Talk with people about your paper topic (Prof. Dove, the TA, other professors, colleagues, mentors, etc.) You are going to spend a lot of energy and time on the paper no matter what, and it pays off to make it something that you can be proud of later and that will be useful in your career. The best way to do this is to include others during the writing process and utilize their input to improve the paper.
Be open minded. Look to ask questions from a different perspective.
